<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl:
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>

explanation: No suspicious pointer usages found relating to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. The only pointer parameters in the provided code are the host_name arguments of OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl and OS_NetworkGetHostName. Both are used as output buffers (calls gethostname(host_name, ...), explicitly write host_name[name_len - 1] = 0, and on error set host_name[0] = 0). Because the pointed-to data is intentionally modified, these pointers must not be const-qualified; therefore they do not violate the requirement that pointers should be const-qualified whenever possible. No other pointer objects or parameters appear in the provided fragments that could be made const.
